abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Technology
            Development Project for China was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            the overly complex procurement procedures adversely affected
            the efficient procuring of advanced research equipment and
            technology. Although procurement delays are common to all
            Bank projects, it was particularly detrimental in this case
            given the rapid obsolescence of the equipment and
            technologies to be acquired. Almost all parties concerned
            contributed to the overall delay of the process: (a) local
            procedures were cumbersome: it took 2-3 months for MEIO
            (Mechanical, Electrical Import/Export Office) to complete
            the review process, something that is beyond the control of
            the implementing agency; (b) Engineering Research Centers
            (ERCs) also contributed to the delay either through delay in
            submission of necessary information/documentation for
            procurement process, and in some cases, holding off
            procurement decision in anticipation of newer technology
            which will be in the market in a few months time; (c)
            procurement agencies: due to lack of comprehensive
            experience in processing Bank projects and following Bank
            procurement guidelines, much unnecessary delays occurred;
            (d) Bank procedure is cumbersome: The process of converting
            the ERCs into corporations raised many problems of asset
            allocation, ownership definition and the establishment of
            new management rules. Due to the diversity of product lines
            as well as manufacturing sectors included in this Project,
            the conversion experience and all the problems encountered
            could serve as lessons for all future prospective
            conversions for a wide array of state owned enterprises.
            Given the number and dispersion of the ERCs, this proved an
            impossible task. Instead of asking for a total coverage, it
            may have been better to settle for a sample. The performance
            of selected ERCs could have been easier to follow in details.

18225210.trustfund: TF022337-TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF022055-ENVIRONMENTAL INITIATIVE FOR ASIA/WID
18225210.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Technology and
            Development project is to support the government's
            continuing reforms in technology policy and institutions so
            as to promote the development of clean, productivity
            enhancing technologies in China's industries. The
            project is designed to accelerate diffusion and adaptation
            of technologies in China and abroad through the deepening of
            technology markets and through institutional initiatives.
            The project will consist of two components. The first
            component is designed to assist in transforming part of the
            research and development establishment (R & D) into
            market-responsive technology development and
            service-oriented elements of existing research institutions
            to create -- through a competitive selection process -- new,
            market-oriented entities, called Engineering Research
            Centers (ERCs). The second component comprises complementary
            investments in improving technology public services,
            including: 1) the modernization of the National Institute of
            Metrology and 2) technical assistance program for a
            Productivity Center as well as for several training activities.
